reviewText:
The Graveyard is quite possibly the simplest game I have ever played. You play as an elderly lady in a graveyard and your only possible action is to walk forwards until you reach a bench and sit down. A song then plays for a few minutes and you either get up before the song ends or you remain and quietly die. That is the entire game.

Interestingly enough, for a game that has absolutely no gameplay The Graveyard actually has a gamebreaking bug. If you remain seated during the song and die you will be forced to use ALT-F4 to end the game as the only real way to exit is to get up before the song ends.

Poetry, Art, Experience. I do like that there are game developers out there that are experimenting with new things but charging gullible consumers money to play, what is essentially a postcard where you have to press the forward key for a few seconds to see it all, is just dishonest and greedy.

This is not a game, some might consider it art. I consider it a money grab.

reviewText:
If you're considering buying this, don't.

I get that this is supposed to be a small, artsy endeavor that shouldn't really even be classified as a game properly. I do. I've actually played other 'games' like that. The thing is, those were mostly very well done. This is crap.

It uses standard wasd controls, but a and d turn instead of strafe. This makes movement awkward unless you're going straight forward. Fortunately(?), the camera angle is fixed and you have literally nowhere else to go because invisible walls block you from leaving the path forward in any meaningful way. Technically, you can travel a brief distance down the side paths before encountering them, but that hardly makes any difference.

The worst part, really, is that it fails even at what should be its strength. The movements are poorly executed and frequently fail to match up properly with the environment. The birds, about the only moving things in the game apart from the protagonist, constantly clip through objects such as your character and the pavement. And the art assets themselves, even on highest settings, are mediocre at best in comparison with other 3D games of the last 5 years or more, and often considerably shabbier.

Your experience of the game will not even vary in any significant way as near as I can tell. You will walk her to the end of the path where she will sit on the bench. Then, a transparent profile of her will appear along the right side of the screen, and a song about death sung in German plays, with subtitles. At some point during this song, she will die.

The instructions are misleading, as they say you will walk her back out of the graveyard, ending the game, after it is done. I did three playthroughs, altering various things to try and see if she would survive so that I could, indeed, walk her back out and end the game properly, including going very slowly and letting her rest frequently and at length, in case it was linked to overexertion (perhaps as a way of punishing the player for not taking the time to appropriately appreciate this 'art'?). In the end, nothing worked. One of the only things I did not try was turning clockwise to sit down on the bench instead of counter-clockwise, and the idea that this could be the deciding factor is asinine, and I refuse to waste any more time experimenting with it because the game is so tedious and boring.

I honestly don't even know why this is for sale. I could see this being made as a hobby project or maybe some kind of tech demo, but charging money for it seems almost unconscionable. This is easily in the running for the worst game on Steam.

In short, if you still have any interest in this, just watch a youtube video of a playthrough instead. You'll get the exact same experience minus pressing the w key and then a or d to turn around and sit (which she does automatically). Don't waste your money on it.

Yesterday I was taking a walk in the park, I sat down near a lake and pulled out a sandwich I had bought at a nearby deli. I was stricken by an overwhelming sense of serenity and appreciation. Over out at the lake there sat an island with a giant tree, who's branches had been made home to a number of birds nests. From the lake, I could catch sight of elderly men fishing, children playing with bread crumbs and ducks, a couple holding hands and taking a walk, a shirtless man on a jog, two women passing by on a bike. Every one of them wrapped up in their own world, but all the same, part of an ecological system that brought upon a feeling of peace, safety, and a certain pure beauty that made me aware of just how nice the cool breeze felt running across my skin from the hot summer heat, the underlying frailness of some waterside flowers that reflected beautifully on the lake's surface, and the pleasures of smell the fauna brought simply from its own life and death cycle.

None of that resonated in this lifeless game, it has absolutely no artistic merit, and the song sucked.

10/10, would put my wrinkly old woman butt on a bench again.

reviewText:
This game was truly inspirational. Gifted to me by a close and dear friend, known for his witty choice of games, I was originally skeptical. The download for the game was quick and efficient. Upon first opening the game you are thrown straight into the gameplay, this originally threw me off guard as the controls were quite hard to get used to. However with perseverance anything can be achieved. After I had fully mastered the controls I began the game, before playing I advise you get headphones to play as the music is truly inspirational and the game is not complete without it.
The first thing you see after starting the game is a divinely animated graveyard with a variety of different grave designs included. The lady you control moves at a smooth speed, which one could compare to a the speed of which a snail moves towards a particularly appetisizing piece of grass. The goal is far in the distance though, being not as smart as many players who had played this game prior to me I had to check the menu, which can be found by pressing the escape key. The goal is to get to the bench in the center of the graveyard. On the way towards the bench I found myself going on a journey into my inner consciousness, questioning my very existence upon this world. To sit down on the bench upon arrival you must slowly direct the lady backwards onto the bench until she glimpses poetically back at the bench before firmly placing herself on it. This is where the real story begins.

Sitting on the bench transports you to an entirely new plain of existence. This is the part of the game which you definately need headphones for as the music here is both emotive and inspiring. Though the song sang is in german it speaks to you on an emotional level, without reading the lyrics I instantly knew everything the song was saying and I almost felt as though I was the lady I controlled. The emotions of her past flooded into my mind, emotions I have never felt before and I am sure I will never feel again. To my suprise once the song ended the lady did not wake up and I now know this happened because it is possible in rare circumstances for the lady to die, of natural causes, during the game. This came as a shock to me and something shifted inside my heart. Why was I chosen to witness this" I have asked myself every night before I fall asleep and the only answer I could find was that I had been chosen by her.
Writing this review I am finding it hard to control my urge to cry as this game has truly touched me in many ways.
Masterpieces like this are hard to find these days so I strongly suggest you buy this game.
Well done Tell a Tale games. 10/10."

reviewText:
This game caught my eye in the steam store, and it seemed mysterious enough to warrant spending $2.50 (there was a sale).  I loaded it up and was instantly assaulted by spinning .jpeg trees.  I ignored those though, instead focusing on the atmosphere.  As I made my way to the bench, the futility of it all slowly grasped me.  I began to think about what the old woman had been through - how many of the graves surrounding us were her friends?  Her kin?

As I urged the woman ever closer to the bench, I began to feel that we shared the struggle - and furthermore, that it was a pointless one.  I thought that maybe if we just gave up, it would all end.  Was there really a reason to keep moving forward?  To crawl through life with nothing to live for?  The game became real to me...  And then we reached the bench.

As soon as we sat down, this god-awful song started playing.  It completely destroyed the atmosphere, and the emotions that were building up in my mind.  And it lasted for minutes.  After it finally ended, the struggle of moving through the graveyard became a race to end the game as quickly as possible.  In the description of the game it says that it's supposed tell a story without words, but there was a lot of those in that horrible, horrible song.

If that was removed from the game, I would rate it positively.  As it is, I'd give it 2/10.  I know it's harsh to rate it so low, but the song took up a good half of my playthrough, and ruined the last walking sequence.  Therefore only the first couple minutes were actually worth playing.  You done goof'd.

tl;dr: I got attached to the woman because my vivid imagination made it all very real.  After we reached the bench, the whole dark little world I had built up in my mind was shattered by that terrible song.  2/10





And yes, it took me more time to write this review than to play through the game.
